column2: The place of the dead, or of souls after death; the grave; -- called in Hebrew sheol, and by the Greeks hades.
column3: The place or state of punishment for the wicked after death; the abode of evil spirits. Hence, any mental torment; anguish.
column4: A place where outcast persons or things are gathered
column5: A dungeon or prison; also, in certain running games, a place to which those who are caught are carried for detention.
column7: A place into which a tailor throws his shreds, or a printer his broken type.

column4: To move, proceed, advance, pass, go, come, etc., swiftly, smoothly, or with quick action; -- said of things animate or inanimate. Hence, to flow, glide, or roll onward, as a stream, a snake, a wagon, etc.; to move by quicker action than in walking, as a person, a horse, a dog.
column5: To go swiftly; to pass at a swift pace; to hasten.
column6: To flee, as from fear or danger.
column7: To steal off; to depart secretly.
column8: To contend in a race; hence, to enter into a contest; to become a candidate; as, to run for Congress.
column9: To pass from one state or condition to another; to come into a certain condition; -- often with in or into; as, to run into evil practices; to run in debt.
column10: To exert continuous activity; to proceed; as, to run through life; to run in a circle.
column11: To pass or go quickly in thought or conversation; as, to run from one subject to another.
column12: To discuss; to continue to think or speak about something; -- with on.
column13: To make numerous drafts or demands for payment, as upon a bank; -- with on.
column15: To flow, as a liquid; to ascend or descend; to course; as, rivers run to the sea; sap runs up in the spring; her blood ran cold.
column16: To proceed along a surface; to extend; to spread.
column17: To become fluid; to melt; to fuse.
column18: To turn, as a wheel; to revolve on an axis or pivot; as, a wheel runs swiftly round.
column19: To travel; to make progress; to be moved by mechanical means; to go; as, the steamboat runs regularly to Albany; the train runs to Chicago.
column20: To extend; to reach; as, the road runs from Philadelphia to New York; the memory of man runneth not to the contrary.
column21: To go back and forth from place to place; to ply; as, the stage runs between the hotel and the station.
column22: To make progress; to proceed; to pass.
column23: To continue in operation; to be kept in action or motion; as, this engine runs night and day; the mill runs six days in the week.
column24: To have a course or direction; as, a line runs east and west.
column25: To be in form thus, as a combination of words.
column26: To be popularly known; to be generally received.
column27: To have growth or development; as, boys and girls run up rapidly.
column28: To tend, as to an effect or consequence; to incline.
column29: To spread and blend together; to unite; as, colors run in washing.
column30: To have a legal course; to be attached; to continue in force, effect, or operation; to follow; to go in company; as, certain covenants run with the land.
column31: To continue without falling due; to hold good; as, a note has thirty days to run.
column32: To discharge pus or other matter; as, an ulcer runs.
column33: To be played on the stage a number of successive days or nights; as, the piece ran for six months.
column34: To sail before the wind, in distinction from reaching or sailing closehauled; -- said of vessels.
column35: Specifically, of a horse: To move rapidly in a gait in which each leg acts in turn as a propeller and a supporter, and in which for an instant all the limbs are gathered in the air under the body.
column36: To move rapidly by springing steps so that there is an instant in each step when neither foot touches the ground; -- so distinguished from walking in athletic competition.
column37: To cause to run (in the various senses of Run, v. i.); as, to run a horse; to run a stage; to run a machine; to run a rope through a block.
column38: To pursue in thought; to carry in contemplation.
column39: To cause to enter; to thrust; as, to run a sword into or through the body; to run a nail into the foot.
column40: To drive or force; to cause, or permit, to be driven.
column41: To fuse; to shape; to mold; to cast; as, to run bullets, and the like.
column42: To cause to be drawn; to mark out; to indicate; to determine; as, to run a line.
column43: To cause to pass, or evade, offical restrictions; to smuggle; -- said of contraband or dutiable goods.
column44: To go through or accomplish by running; as, to run a race; to run a certain career.
column45: To cause to stand as a candidate for office; to support for office; as, to run some one for Congress.
column46: To encounter or incur, as a danger or risk; as, to run the risk of losing one's life. See To run the chances, below.
column47: To put at hazard; to venture; to risk.
column48: To discharge; to emit; to give forth copiously; to be bathed with; as, the pipe or faucet runs hot water.
column49: To be charged with, or to contain much of, while flowing; as, the rivers ran blood.
column50: To conduct; to manage; to carry on; as, to run a factory or a hotel.
column51: To tease with sarcasms and ridicule.
column52: To sew, as a seam, by passing the needle through material in a continuous line, generally taking a series of stitches on the needle at the same time.
column53: To migrate or move in schools; -- said of fish; esp., to ascend a river in order to spawn.
column54: The act of running; as, a long run; a good run; a quick run; to go on the run.
column55: A small stream; a brook; a creek.
column56: That which runs or flows in the course of a certain operation, or during a certain time; as, a run of must in wine making; the first run of sap in a maple orchard.
column57: A course; a series; that which continues in a certain course or series; as, a run of good or bad luck.
column58: State of being current; currency; popularity.
column59: Continued repetition on the stage; -- said of a play; as, to have a run of a hundred successive nights.
column60: A continuing urgent demand; especially, a pressure on a bank or treasury for payment of its notes.
column61: A range or extent of ground for feeding stock; as, a sheep run.
column62: The aftermost part of a vessel's hull where it narrows toward the stern, under the quarter.
column63: The distance sailed by a ship; as, a good run; a run of fifty miles.
column64: A voyage; as, a run to China.
column66: The horizontal distance to which a drift may be carried, either by license of the proprietor of a mine or by the nature of the formation; also, the direction which a vein of ore or other substance takes.
column67: A roulade, or series of running tones.
column68: The greatest degree of swiftness in marching.  It is executed upon the same principles as the double-quick, but with greater speed.
column69: The act of migrating, or ascending a river to spawn; -- said of fish; also, an assemblage or school of fishes which migrate, or ascend a river for the purpose of spawning.
column70: In baseball, a complete circuit of the bases made by a player, which enables him to score one; in cricket, a passing from one wicket to the other, by which one point is scored; as, a player made three runs; the side went out with two hundred runs.
column71: A pair or set of millstones.
column72: Melted, or made from molten material; cast in a mold; as, run butter; run iron or lead.

column2: To strike, thrust, or hit violently with the foot; as, a horse kicks a groom; a man kicks a dog.
column3: To thrust out the foot or feet with violence; to strike out with the foot or feet, as in defense or in bad temper; esp., to strike backward, as a horse does, or to have a habit of doing so. Hence, figuratively: To show ugly resistance, opposition, or hostility; to spurn.
column4: To recoil; -- said of a musket, cannon, etc.
column5: A blow with the foot or feet; a striking or thrust with the foot.
column6: The projection on the tang of the blade of a pocket knife, which prevents the edge of the blade from striking the spring. See Illust. of Pocketknife.
column7: A projection in a mold, to form a depression in the surface of the brick.
column8: The recoil of a musket or other firearm, when discharged.

column2: A Chinese musical instrument, consisting of resonant stones or metal plates, arranged according to their tones in a frame of wood, and struck with a hammer.
column3: A chief ruler; a sovereign; one invested with supreme authority over a nation, country, or tribe, usually by hereditary succession; a monarch; a prince.
column4: One who, or that which, holds a supreme position or rank; a chief among competitors; as, a railroad king; a money king; the king of the lobby; the king of beasts.
column5: A playing card having the picture of a king; as, the king of diamonds.
column6: The chief piece in the game of chess.
column7: A crowned man in the game of draughts.
column8: The title of two historical books in the Old Testament.
column9: To supply with a king; to make a king of; to raise to royalty.

column3: To make safe; to procure the safety of; to preserve from injury, destruction, or evil of any kind; to rescue from impending danger; as, to save a house from the flames.
column4: Specifically, to deliver from sin and its penalty; to rescue from a state of condemnation and spiritual death, and bring into a state of spiritual life.
column5: To keep from being spent or lost; to secure from waste or expenditure; to lay up; to reserve.
column6: To rescue from something undesirable or hurtful; to prevent from doing something; to spare.
column7: To hinder from doing, suffering, or happening; to obviate the necessity of; to prevent; to spare.
column8: To hold possession or use of; to escape loss of.
column9: To avoid unnecessary expense or expenditure; to prevent waste; to be economical.
column10: Except; excepting; not including; leaving out; deducting; reserving; saving.
